Characterization and the hermeneutics of recognition in Virginia Woolf’s The Voyage Out

ABSTRACT
This article traces Virginia Woolf’s interest in the representation of women back to her first published novel, The Voyage Out (1915). It argues that her dissatisfaction with traditional modes of women’s characterization stems from their reliance on recognizable patriarchal models of personhood, an unhealthy dependence which restricts the development of new forms of gendered political and personal identification. This reading uses the concept of recognition, as understood in the post-Hegelian feminist tradition, as a key structuring and interpretative tool to demonstrate Woolf’s early critical insight into the fraught relationship between idealized narratives of individual autonomy and gender. In doing so, it makes a case for the broader inclusion of recognition as a critical term of inquiry in modernist studies, both as an aesthetic and political site of contention.


Introduction
Virginia Woolf’s contemporaries often highlight characterization as a flaw in her writing practice. This common critical trope accompanies the publications of all her novels, starting with the very first, The Voyage Out (1915). An unsigned review in the Nation, for example, declares it “hardly a work of art. Partly because of its form, partly because it is too passionately intent upon vivisection.” Despite offering generous praise for the execution of nearly every other aspect of the text, E. M. Forster finds that the “characters are not vivid. [ … ] they do not stroll out of their sentences, and even develop a tendency to merge shadow-like.”Woolf’s reactions to such comments were initially confined to her diaries and personal correspondence and ranged from frustration to acquiescence. Towards the end of the 1910s and early 1920s, however, they began to take a more distinct and public shape as a loose theory of modern fiction, developed in celebrated essays such as “Modern Novels” (1919), “Reading” (1919), “Mr Bennett and Mrs Brown” (1923/4), and “Character in Fiction” (1924).Footnote3

The clamor of voices decrying the insufficiencies of modernist characters was a common feature in the critical landscape of the day, particularly when discussing novels of development and education, like The Voyage Out. As Jed Esty argues modernists often tried to circumvent the Bildungsroman’s “generic dictates or to revise them out of recognition.”Footnote4 As a result, their modifications of the traditional developmental trajectories followed by its protagonists, associated with a process of learning and successful adaptation to social norms, tend to “block or defer the attainment of a mature social role.”Footnote5 For Esty, Woolf’s novel accomplishes just such an intervention through the workings of its plot and setting, which position its characters firmly within the histories of colonial contact, displacement, and migration.Footnote6 Susan Stanford Friedman also focuses on the text’s challenges to the “orthodoxies of representation” and its defiance of the “boundaries of expectation as these have been erected by literary tradition.”Footnote7 This reading concentrates explicitly on the function of women in the successful execution of the marriage plot and raises important questions about the role of gender in conventionally constructed narratives of development. The category of the “female Bildungsroman,” under which The Voyage Out was classified by early critics, has been in feminist critical parlance since at least the 1970s, chiefly occupying itself with investigating how women writers in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries represented “the suppression and defeat of female autonomy, creativity, and maturity by patriarchal gender norms.”Footnote8 In their well-known study in this tradition, Elizabeth Abel, Marianne Hirsch, and Elizabeth Langland, argue that the traditional Bildungsroman excludes gender “as a pertinent category,” an omission that has had direct effects on the dominant models for its “narrative structure,” “psychology,” and “representation of social pressures.”Footnote9 What is more, reading the history of the Bildungsroman as a document of the development of modern subjectivity, “one could be tempted to conclude that the gender of modernity is indeed male,” an impression, which, as Rita Felski states, calls for a sustained critique of the “idealized representation of the autonomous male subject.”Footnote10

As I will argue in what follows, Woolf’s first novel engages in performing precisely this task and in doing so exhibits the development of a related interest in Woolf’s thought. That is, the representation of women in fiction as a political problem, which is brought to bear on the aesthetic strategies of character construction and the hermeneutic practices employed to interpret them. Consequently, this article places emphasis on character, rather than plot formation, in order to bring to light Woolf’s early insight into the regulatory power of reading norms. While the Bildungsroman plot in The Voyage Out allows Woolf to formulate a direct challenge to the narrative of development, as it relates to women’s lives, her concerns go beyond a criticism of the limited social positions they are allowed to occupy.Footnote11 Directing her critical focus towards traditional models of characterization, heavily underwritten by the ideal of self-determination, shows that she identifies the very construction of the subject, in and through the normative conditions of power relations that shape our experiences as gendered and embodied agents, as a site of contention, anticipating much contemporary feminist theory on the topic. Furthermore, it lays the foundation of her critique of institutionalism and the forms of knowledge it engenders and propagates, which she elaborates more completely through her essays and novels of the 1920s and 1930s. As stated by Stephanie J. Brown in a recent essay, feminist approaches to Woolf’s writing have been successful in instilling the importance of attending carefully to her “growing conviction that existing institutions are structured by an ineradicably patriarchal logic, and therefore inadequate to the needs of women and to the requirements of a just society.”Footnote12 Elucidating the ways in which Woolf sees this inadequacy as functioning through the narrative and hermeneutic norms which govern the literary representations of personhood, is the main objective of this article.

To begin this discussion, I would like to return to the term “recognition,” used in passing by Esty. Despite playing an important role within larger histories of ideas associated with personal autonomy and democratic social organization, the concept of recognition has been insufficiently developed in literary studies, as Felski has recently observed.Footnote13 Some consideration of recognition has taken place, mainly as a principle of poetics, derived from the Aristotelian notion of anagnorisis, which is generally understood to signify a moment of transition from ignorance to knowledge.Footnote14 These reflections have largely taken place within a framework of realist forms of representation, which tend to rely on a narrative logic of an inevitable revelation of purpose and meaning, a feature very much in operation within the Bildugnsroman, and one, which, as outlined above, the modernist novel of this kind tends to undermine. Hence, recognition in this sense, despite its customary operation as a principle of identity construction, has been deemed largely immaterial for modernist criticism in general, and feminist modernist criticism in particular. The larger political point encoded within the problem of recognition as an organizational device in fiction, which often evades detection, is brought into focus by Woolf’s narrative of her young protagonist, Rachel Vinrace, who undertakes the task of becoming a socially recognizable individual within the context of a patriarchal economy of knowledge.Footnote15 The novel stages Rachel’s engagement as the culmination of this educational process, the narrative and hermeneutic end of the literary imagination, followed by the young heroine’s death. In a sense, this is the highest form anagnorisis can attain and its ultimate limitation – fiction constructed on this model, cannot see beyond that which is knowable, or even that which is known. As Ben Parker observes, it is at the point that the Aristotelian notion begins to acquire Hegelian echoes. “The logic of recognition,” he writes, “presumes an ultimate knowability: the truth of subjectivity requires a detour though otherness,” a detour obstructed under the conditions of capitalist modernity and the norms of identity development it espouses.Footnote16

Contemporary political theories of recognition also trace back to Hegel. His concept of Anerkennung as developed in the Phenomenology of Spirit (1807) is concerned with the constitution of knowing subjects, which he sees not as an isolated activity, but one which must be performed in communion with others: “[s]elf-consciousness exists in and for itself when, and by the fact that, it so exists for another self-another; that is, it exists only in being acknowledged.”Footnote17 This process upholds for Hegel the infinite nature of this two-fold exchange in dialectical opposition to the determinateness of self-consciousness. In other words, the subject has to be recognized by others and have its claims to personhood validated through intersubjective acknowledgement within the social sphere in order to escape the laws of its own determination. This also leads to establishing an autonomous sense of self and the creation of ethical obligations for the treatment of others. However, receiving and granting recognition under conditions of social inequality raises questions about the hierarchies of value generated by this exchange. Feminist philosophers continue to dispute the usefulness of recognition as a formative principle for democratic social structures, within which women can find emancipation. A significant voice in these debates is Judith Butler, whose concerns regarding the concept and its relationship to oppression are deep and persistent, as further discussion below will demonstrate. The benefits of reading Woolf in tandem with Butler have been brought into sharp focus by Elsa Högberg, who examines the practice of recognition as an ethical counterpart to the problem of violence in the work of both authors. While Högberg’s study focuses on the interwar novels, from Jacob’s Room (1922) to The Waves (1931), my analysis locates Woolf’s interest in constructing new “aesthetic strategies for reconfiguring individuality” at an even earlier moment, in her debut novel.Footnote18 It also explicitly takes up these strategies’ gendered dimensions, focalized in The Voyage Out through Rachel’s course of development towards acquiring a recognizable form of personhood in keeping with the limitations imposed by her social position as a young woman.

Striving for recognition
Judith Butler understands recognition as an essential aspect both of self-formation and interpersonal relations, part of a reciprocal communal exchange, for which “we are all, in different ways, striving.”Footnote19 This is to say that recognition is a common human condition, a token of validation we require to affirm our existence as functioning agents within the social sphere. This fundamental reliance, for Butler, engenders certain dependencies which make us vulnerable to others as well as to the very norms that govern our relations with the wider world. In The Psychic Life of Power, she outlines this situation as one of “primary dependency [which] conditions the political formation and regulation of the subject and becomes the means of their subjection.”Footnote20 The subject then is “formed in submission” to power “that at first appears as external, pressed upon the subject,” but in “pressing the subject into subordination, assumes a psychic form that constitutes the subject’s self-identity.”Footnote21 This relationship within which personhood is born, is one that “initiates and sustains our agency” but also restricts and controls it.Footnote22 The concept of recognition, on this account, becomes implicated in practices of control, prevalent within the paradigmatic structure of power relations that shape the individual within a patriarchal context. Despite its subordinating power, however, recognition continues to be a necessary process due to our psychic and social need for it. In Butler’s view, the subject in the process of self-formation either has to accept this form of subordinating relations or forgo participation in social life altogether. Both options prove undesirable, in different ways, harboring the illusion of a meaningful choice. The resistance strategy she offers is framed through a process of re-signification of the terms and practices individuals utilize to counter the prevalent logic of subjection such as forms of “critical desubjectivation” and “incoherence of identity.”Footnote23

Woolf’s position, as it emerges in The Voyage Out itself and later essays carries more ambiguity. In the first instance, she situates recognition within the reading process, as a tool of characterization, and acknowledges its instrumental function for engendering a productive connection between writer, reader, and text. In “Character in Fiction,” she states that

[t]he writer must get into touch with his reader by putting before him something which he recognises, which therefore stimulates his imagination, and makes him co-operate in the far more difficult business of intimacy. And it is of the highest importance that this common meeting-place should be reached easily, almost instinctively, in the dark, with one’s eyes shut.Footnote24

A shared experience emerges from this state of being in common with others. Establishing this intersubjective “meeting-place” relies on a relationship of recognition between the reader and the forms of personhood they encounter in the text. When left to work in peace, the norms of judgement determine the types of fictional representation that can be recognized as characteristic of personhood. When they are meddled with, the entire socio-epistemological functioning of the reading process is endangered. The difficulty Woolf identifies for the writer is that the construction of a common space around a practice of recognition can constrain the emergence of new forms of identification, as well as the author’s aesthetic field of experimentation. This complication, also formulated by Butler, arises through the demand to give an account of oneself, or to become legible, within the social sphere. In doing this, the subject is confronted with the exchange of their singularity for a measure of recognizability. “If I try to give an account of myself,” she states:
if I try to make myself recognizable and understandable [ … ] I will, to some degree, have to make myself substitutable in order to make myself recognizable. The narrative authority of the “I” must give way to the perspective and temporality of a set of norms that contest the singularity of my own story.Footnote25

In The Voyage Out, Rachel comes to experience this demand directly on several occasions, usually when asked to introduce herself. During an outing, St John Hirst, one of her companions, proposes that each member of their party should provide “a short biographical sketch.”Footnote26 In response, Rachel states that she is “twenty-four years of age, the daughter of a ship-owner, that she had never been properly educated; played the piano, had no brothers or sisters, and lived at Richmond with her aunts, her mother being dead” (159). This matter-of-fact description is only comparable in substance to the Who’s Who compendium of short biographies of famous historical figures Rachel reads on board her father’s ship, which takes her to the fictional colonial location of Santa Marina, where most of the novel’s action takes place.Footnote27 She issues this string of facts, referring to her age, class, educational status, family history, and her sole occupation efficiently and impersonally, as if in fear or under duress, each comma marking yet another aspect of her social personhood. She presents herself as a common, not a singular being, one of many, her identity not porous, but impermeable, forged under the pressure of the unforgivable inevitability of norms.
Terence Hewet, an aspiring novelist, and Rachel’s future fiancée, also challenges her to give an account of herself. At Terence’s prompt, “Rachel,” the narrator states, “lost her freedom and became self-conscious. She felt herself at once singular and under observation” (245). For Felski, this would constitute a moment of recognition, which, unlike Butler, she sees as a potentially generative experience. When we engage in a process of recognition, she writes, “we make sense of what is unfamiliar by fitting it into an existing scheme, linking it to what we already know.”Footnote28 But this initial connection with the norms we recognize does not have to produce an experience that is repetitive, derivative, or in any way subordinating. Instead, it could show us things in a new light, compelling us to imagine a “revised or altered sense of who I am.”Footnote29 On her reading, the self-conscious moment can simultaneously serve “as a social diagnosis and an ethical judgement.”Footnote30 As a result, she advocates preserving a certain epistemological openness, which harbors the potential to create new forms of self-knowledge that can be taken up by the subject through a phenomenological relation of “self-scrutiny rather than self-loss.”Footnote31

The startling experience of self-consciousness, provoked in Rachel by Terence’s demand, however, is presented by Woolf as inimical to her freedom. Overwhelmed by the demands of recognition, the self-realization that she must become intelligible as a subject of norms threatens her capacity for generating self-knowledge. The realization that he sees her as a woman additionally inhibits Rachel’s ability to communicate an individual position. Furthermore, she feels constrained and “hampered,” the necessity of self-scrutiny only revealing more loss of possibility (246–7). In this moment of self-consciousness Rachel comprehends her dependence on Terence and her own vulnerability, exposing Woolf’s own critique of recognition predicated on the certainty of knowledge as model of emancipation. Instead, Rachel’s freedom is diminished, she becomes an object of enquiry, of knowledge, and of desire, which can be mastered and acquired by others.Footnote32 Once she perceives her newly drawn outline produced through Terence’s recognition of her womanhood, she is compelled to inhabit it by modifying or relinquishing other fragments of her identity. In this way, the norm prevails, forcing an act of dispossession.Footnote33 Louise DeSalvo draws attention to the differences between the first English edition of the novel and the first American one, published five years later, at this crucial moment in the development of the relationship between Rachel and Terence. The American edition, DeSalvo observes, offers a more combative Rachel, who refuses to be “pinned down by any second person,” which demonstrates Woolf’s heightened attention to emphasizing the disbalance in the hermeneutic positions which Rachel and Terence occupy in this exchange.Footnote34 Rachel never demands a reciprocal account from Terence, allowing him the possibility to escape self-scrutiny and categorization. The novel purposefully refuses to represent this exchange between the two lovers as reciprocal and equal, a point which serves to complicate models of analysing ethical readings of recognition as “dyadic encounters,” which tend to equalize the power both agents hold in the validation of one another.Footnote35 In the context of a social infrastructure built upon networks of patriarchal power, Woolf seems to be suggesting, the position of women in this exercise, is one of deep disadvantage. In this sense, the common meeting place becomes less of a democratic locus for reinvention and more of a battleground for survival.

Becoming a person
Early in the novel, Rachel is described as someone who is struggling to become a person. The prime impediments to this are associated with her ability to adequately employ her rational faculties, accumulate knowledge, and exercise command over her language. “A hesitation in speaking,” the narrator observes, “or rather a tendency to use the wrong words, made her seem more than normally incompetent for her years” (15–16). Further on we are told that “her eyes were unreflecting as water” and “her mind was absent” (17). As Allison Pease notes, this is not an unusual representation of womanhood in early twentieth-century literature. Rachel “has failed the qualifications of post-Cartesian selfhood,” she “knows nothing; she thinks and feels, but she is an outsider to a system that produces knowing individuals.”Footnote36 The inability to find the words to express her thoughts is a source of confusion both for Rachel herself and the people around her. Her preference for musical over literary forms of expression, reflective of her discomfort with explicit verbal identifications, is evident throughout the text. As a result, Rachel is seen as someone who is not possessed of the ability to generate rational certainty, making this one of the main issues in terms of her characterization. Emma Sutton connects this to her “inarticulateness” and the difficulties of expressing the intense richness of inner thought through the limited commands of spoken language.Footnote37 Molly Hite goes even further to suggest that in favoring “an inherently nonrepresentational” art of expression for Rachel, Woolf curates “an aesthetic form that invents rather than represents.”Footnote38 Music creates modalities of connection and identification that are non-structural and non-hierarchical, and allow Rachel to give full expression to the complexities of her interiority without having to negotiate the struggle for recognition.

In a novel, whose characters’ chief occupation, as Eric Sandberg observes, is “defining, or characterizing, other people,” Rachel’s lack of clear outline presents a puzzle.Footnote39 In addition to failing the Cartesian principles of selfhood, rooted in rational self-examination, she seems to lack awareness of the gendered aspects of socialization. Mrs Helen Ambrose, her aunt, functions as a figure of female authority, whose role is to induct Rachel in traditional practices of womanhood, including those associated with motherhood and marriage. She takes it upon herself to “enlighten” (105) the young woman, whose sheltered upbringing by her two (unmarried) aunts, following the death of her mother, according to Helen, is the reason why she appears so removed from worldly interpersonal affairs, especially those associated with sexual desire. Rachel’s encounter with Mr Dalloway on the ship to Santa Marina, provides a brief and unwelcome disclosure in this regard. During one of their brief conversations, he prompts: “‘[ … ] Now tell me about yourself. What are your interests and occupations?’” Rachel responds: “‘You see, I’m a woman’” (79).Footnote40 Her admission is met with an outburst of passion, which moves Mr Dalloway to assault her with a kiss, following which he misdirects responsibility for the violent act and accuses her of temptation. The direct second-person address, “‘You tempt me,’” summons an act of individual agency Rachel is unable to account for (80). Her resulting feelings range from discomfort to fear, she is unable to sleep and stop thinking about the experience, feeling persecuted and entrapped. She confides in Helen, who simply explains that this is the way things are between men and women: “it’s the most natural thing in the world” (86). This leads Rachel to formulate a link between herself and “those women in Piccadilly,” who her aunt confirms are prostitutes (86). As Hite emphasizes, “the existence and meaning of the prostitute are of acute importance to a young girl entering the arena of sexual arrangements.”Footnote41 The topic emerges again in a discussion with Evelyn Murgatroyd, another character in the novel, who is trying to navigate her marriage prospects, when it is explicitly linked to the economic foundations of marriage, understood as a “relation of sexual ownership.”Footnote42 The process of becoming a person recognizable by others for Rachel, as for Evelyn, and the rest of the women in the novel, is inevitably tied with negotiating the terms on which their bodies will be interpreted, valued, and possessed. The moment of confrontation with patriarchal sexuality leads Rachel to see “her life for the first time [as] a creeping hedged-in thing, driven cautiously between high walls, here turned aside, there plunged in darkness, made dull and crippled forever” (87). She suddenly starts to understand how gendered expectations restrict and direct behavior. This emerging sense of limitation foregrounds the conflict between the normative rituals associated with Rachel’s “culturally determined destiny” as a wife and mother, as Christine Froula has argued, and her desire to “break out of the female initiation plot that her culture imposes upon women, constituting them not as fully legitimated participants in history and culture.”Footnote43 Woolf’s concerns with this process of legitimation are linked to the institutional hierarchies that create disparities between those who can claim to be possessors of the means of knowledge production and those who can only acquire the resulting outcomes, a distinction which radically alters the balance of power in the practice of recognition.

The Voyage Out interrogates the role literature and practices of reading play in the establishments of these hierarchies, particularly as they relate to the education of women. As Friedman observes, “the reading of people” and “the reading of books” in the novel are often presented as binary opposites – the former related to the social sphere, and generally the domain of women and the latter, linked to the institutional production of knowledge, and thus reserved for men.Footnote44 The politics of reading was a topic that clearly occupied Woolf during the extended composition period of the novel, stretching from 1908 to 1913, during which she completed several essays on the topic.Footnote45 In the novel itself, Rachel receives instruction on her reading by various male characters, including Richard Dalloway, St John Hirst and her uncle, Ridley Ambrose. Mr Dalloway suggests Burke’s writings on the American and French revolutions to induce a development of a political conscience. St John recommends Gibbon’s multivolume history of the Roman empire as a way to test the viability of her mind. Mr Ambrose offers a course of learning based on the contents of his travel library that stretches from Balzac back to Marlowe.Footnote46 In his study, she is allowed to select her own reading and leaves with Le Cousine Bette (1846), a novel which displays women’s insubordinate behavior as a persistent threat to the bourgeois stability of the family unit.

As the narrative develops, it is through the study and performance of literary characters that Rachel begins to take a more definite shape:

“What I want to know,” she said aloud, “is this: What is the truth? What is the truth of it all?” She was speaking partly as herself and partly as the heroine of the play she had just read. [ … ] for the moment she herself was the most vivid thing in it – a heroic statue in the middle of the foreground, dominating the view. Ibsen’s plays always left her in that condition. She acted them for days at a time, greatly to Helen’s amusement; and then it would be Meredith’s turn and she became Diana of the Crossways, but Helen was aware that it was not all acting, and that some sort of change was taking place in the human being. (136–7)

Rachel’s selection of texts focuses on the stories of modern women who inhabit a hostile world and commit various transgressive acts to free themselves from the confines associated with their gender identity.Footnote47 Her choices also reflect a forming idea of social inequality as Ibsen is followed “by a novel such as Mrs Ambrose detested, whose purpose was to distribute the guilt of a woman’s downfall upon the right shoulders” (138). In addition to providing her with examples of womanhood, modern fiction also offers a space for experimentation with language. She reads the shiny, yellow-covered books “with the curious literalness of one to whom written sentences are unfamiliar, and handling words as though they were made of wood, separately of great importance, and possessed of shapes like tables and chairs” (137–8). Rachel uses the language of literary representation to learn the normative shapes and sizes of modern human experience, and particularly that of women, aware that words carry the weight of the meanings ascribed to them. This experience of trying on fictional characters highlights the collaborative force with which language, norms, and forms come together to formulate the recognizable models of identification available to the modern reader.
Rachel’s education and reading practice slowly create an archive of linguistic and behavioral codes to help her construct a picture of a coherent gendered personhood. As her performance within her social circle improves and reaches the expected standard, Mrs Ambrose directly gives her permission to be a person:

“So now you can go ahead and be a person on your own account,” she added. The vision of her own personality, of herself as a real everlasting thing, different from anything else, unmergeable, like the see or the wind, flashed in Rachel’s mind, and she became profoundly excited at the thought of living. (90)

Rachel’s jubilation at this prospect does not materialize in a conscious effort of making herself into a “real everlasting thing”; instead, she slides out of view at every chance of establishing herself, a practice encouraged by her eclectic reading. As Butler argues, the draw towards accounting for oneself as a singular subject, in search for social validation, is a crucial step in the practice of recognition, that inevitably comes to clash with the necessity to do so within a normative framework of social relations. Any such account will have to involve parts that do not belong to the subject, whether because they are linked with the norms that direct her own self-constitution or the norms that guide her expression and intelligibility. In this respect, Butler asserts, “it is only in dispossession that I can and do give an account of myself.”Footnote48 Having “learned something about the social limits to her possibilities,” in Hite’s formulation, Rachel is shown to realize the constrained scope of agential action, determined by the gender norms associated with her self-development, within which she is allowed to operate.Footnote49 The novel also adapts to this disruption of the recognition arc and its “representational strategies” and begins to “define her body more and more in terms of an observer’s gaze,” manifesting its awareness that “the knowledge of and entrance into the public realm involve endangering other kinds of knowledge and other realms of ontological contact.”Footnote50
Entering the public sphere
Following her experience of self-consciousness triggered by the confrontation with Terence’s demand, Rachel perceives that the shapes she can inhabit that can generate recognition in response are always already there, carved out of normative demands. The implied function of recognition as a regulation principle, which determines the forms of identity that can be legitimately adopted within the wider normative order, is exposed during the Sunday church service. Rachel looks at the faces she knows from luncheons, walks, and card games and for the first time regards them as fabricated. This realization triggers a process of Cartesian revelation, which makes her reject “all that she had implicitly believed” (265). She is unsettled by her fellow travelers’ need for validation, which makes them into “slavishly acquiescent [ … ] limpet[s],” who allow themselves to be co-opted within a deeply suspect economy of exchange (265). Rachel’s internal monologue shows her becoming critically aware of the norms of legibility which govern the social order in which she is expected to enlist. This is the closest the novel comes to articulating a scene of recognition in the traditional sense and it is significant that Rachel’s transition from a position of relative inexperience to one of “enlightenment” occurs not as an act of self-reflection, but as one of public reading. In her previous encounters with the male characters who demand an account of herself, she has been evasive, impersonal, but never fully open or entirely paradigmatic as a participant in the economy of desire. Instinctively aware of the threat recognition carries for her own singularity, she is not prepared to be transparent to others, her presence in interpersonal exchanges being marked by a curious elusiveness and withholding of substance. Woolf’s own elusiveness in terms of offering “authorial guidance” functions not only through the presentation of “conflicting tonal cues” in relation to the reading of characters, but through her deliberate refusal to structure her narrative around the recognition coordinates expected of it.Footnote51 In this way, she also expands her critical examination from its initial focus on the normative links that are used to construct the novel as a form primary concerned with the representation of personhood, into the “political stakes of the specific work of literary production.”Footnote52

Woolf’s skeptical attitude towards the function of the literary establishment, which to a large extent determines the relationship between texts, authors, and readers, forms an important part of her larger institutional critique. She is particularly disparaging in her evaluation of the British reading public’s attachment to norms, expectations, and habitual practices. She declares it “a very suggestible and docile creature,” which often persists in supporting commonly held notions. In her view, the public generally wants books to confirm their own view of the world, without much defiance:

[o]ld women have houses. They have fathers. They have incomes. They have hot-water bottles. This is how we know that they are old women. Mr Wells and Mr Bennett and Mr Galsworthy have always taught us that this is the way to recognise them.Footnote53

A relationship of this kind conducted on the basis of supply and demand principles, for Woolf, “ceases to be a means of communication between writer and reader, and becomes instead an obstacle and an impediment.”Footnote54 This misconception of the novel’s function underscores its implied cooperation with the maintenance of established social standards in the context of patriarchal capitalist modernity. As Victoria Baena argues, through a reading of Walter Benjamin’s 1934 essay “The Author as a Producer,” the “role of the intellectual” should be understood “less in terms of political ‘commitment’ than as the writer of works that change or at least challenge the world” – an apt description of Woolf’s statement of intent in her debut novel and a lens through which to read her subsequent experiments with literary work in all its guises, as a form of feminist social criticism.Footnote55
After the church scene, Rachel begins to fade away from the narrative. Her status as a protagonist is repeatedly disrupted and diminished instead of asserted and expanded; until, finally, her death is reduced to a conversation topic after tea. Even when she accepts Terence’s offer of marriage during their visit to an Indigenous village, she is not really a person with a mind of her own, and only echoes the sentiments he offers her, adhering to social protocol.

“You like being with me?” Terence asked. “Yes, with you,” she replied. [ … ] “We are happy together.” He did not seem to be speaking, or she to be hearing. “Very happy,” she answered. [ … ] “We love each other,” Terence said. “We love each other,” she repeated. (316)

Rachel’s position in the novel becomes further obscured as other characters start relating to her as Terence’s fiancée, following the announcement of the engagement. Their previous caution towards her is quickly overcome by her identification as a social presence they can recognize. While returning “Thank You” notes she thinks it strange that “considering how very different these people were, [ … ] they used almost the same sentences when they wrote to congratulate her upon her engagement” (342). Shortly after this, Rachel’s fever overcomes her and she slips out of consciousness.Footnote56 This is the final act of dispossession the novel performs. The form of personhood available to her as a married woman obstructs all other possible accounts she might have wished to draw for herself. Even though Rachel agrees to become Terence’s wife, the norms which govern this decision are not hers to make but are hers to comply with. As Butler asserts,
one invariably struggles with conditions of one’s own life that one could not have chosen. If there is an operation of agency or, indeed, freedom in this struggle, it takes place in the context of an enabling and limiting field of constraint.

By allowing Rachel to break out of the characterization model allocated for women in the Bildungsroman, Woolf undermines the exercise of choice as an expression of agency, and with that the entire foundation on which the “idealized representation of [the] autonomous male subject” rests.Footnote58 Rachel’s disrupted narrative shows that under conditions of patriarchal oppression, the self-determination narrative, mapped out across various points of recognition, becomes another form of control.
Conclusion
In theoretical terms, literary character has almost exclusively been discussed as a universal concept, nearly an ideal, akin to that of the autonomous Kantian subject, and in many ways designed to replicate it. Its failures and successes are decided by the same measure. It is often encumbered by expectations of accuracy, truthfulness, and relatability, which all combine to curate a reading process organized around the principle of recognition, both as an aesthetic and political construct. Woolf, however, saw this as a rather restrictive convention and made her opposition to it the cornerstone of her critical engagement with modern fiction. One of the reasons she questioned recognition-based principles for the construction and reading of fiction was connected to a concern about the potential of this convention to narrow the field of authorial invention and thus obscure the novel’s ability to respond to changing social realities. Another, was a more broadly political one, connected to the representation of women in fiction. Woolf worried that a recognition-based model for the construction of personhood, can be used to support a binary world of power and gender relations, where norms are used to control the formation and expressions of identity and the ways in which they can be legitimized. Woolf’s interest in this project, initiated in her first novel and continued throughout her writing life, is not confined to simply decoding the restrictive and implicit dangers of relying on such models in fiction as well as in life. Her first novel begins the work of proposing a new code of practice that would support more diverse forms of personhood and engender the formation of novel and emancipatory forms of political life. In this project the purpose of the novelist appears to be nothing short of imagining personhood anew, of learning to re-cognize it, and deliver it from the confines of its traditional forms.

English
analyze and provide an overview of the writing style and tone of a scholarly text discussing feminist critiques of literary works.

conversation.content:
.I am going to paste different paragraphs that I’ve written. I want you to analyze and learn writing style and tone.                                     "In 1989, Jane Marcus referred to Djuna Barnes’s Nightwood (1936) as “strangely canonized and largely unread.”Footnote1 “Nightwood,” she argues, “is problematic for the woman reader and unusual for modernism because it is such a tightly closed text, and the narration is so distant and detached.”Footnote2 Marcus’s essay, which analyses Nightwood as a study in abject identities, links the lack of readership with the novel’s failure to function as either a canonical feminist or modernist text. Nightwood lacks “the intimacy of a Colette or Woolf novel” in its resistance to meaning.Footnote3 Nearly twenty years later, Teresa de Lauretis, in her analysis of Nightwood as a meditation on Freud’s sex and death drives, admits to having a similar issue:


I approached this text several times over the years, but it was not until I read Barthes that I understood why I could not go on reading Nightwood: the narrative anchorage eluded me, was too weak or too dispersed; the chain of signifiers would not halt, would not find a resting point where meaning could temporarily congeal.Footnote4


Despite the historical gap and the accumulation of feminist scholarship (roughly 100 book- and journal-articles in the past two decades), the difficulty of giving the novel a feminist meaning remains a challenge for feminist scholarship. In “Melancholic Remedies: Djuna Barnes’s Nightwood as Narrative Theory,” Katherine A. Fama argues that feminist studies like those of Marcus and de Lauretis, celebrating Nightwood’s abject identities and appropriating earlier structural models, “are problematized by Barnes’s own pronounced hostility to identity politics.”Footnote5 Moreover, I would add that such readings fail to address the ways in which Barnes’s novel “bucks narrative, revealing our compulsions to retell, read, and know.”Footnote6 Marcus’s and de Lauretis’s similar difficulties with Nightwood suggest to me that the problem is not just with the novel but with feminist critique itself. Why, I wonder, do feminists persist in trying to locate meaning in narrative where it does not exist?
The answer to this question is best highlighted through Jean Baudrillard’s theory of seduction – admittedly the bête noire of feminism – which helps to underscore some feminists’ reliance on what Baudrillard terms the ideology of production in our readings of novels and history.Footnote7 In Seduction (1979), Baudrillard argues that society is structured through production: our various systems for meaning that rely heavily upon verifiable facts and reality in order to maintain the boundaries of class, race, and gender. The ideology of production includes Freudian psychoanalysis, Marxist economics, and Saussurian linguistics – discourses which reinforce the primacy of sex, work, and language as social values. For Baudrillard, as long as production continues to structure society, hierarchy will inevitably follow. However, Baudrillard also provides a challenge to productive discourse in the form of “seduction”: seduction has the potential to overturn hierarchical powers of production. Although the term is traditionally defined as sexual manipulation, Baudrillard locates seduction in spectacle and artifice. And nowhere does seduction produce meaning.


Everything from cosmetics to animals, from transvestites to actresses, from masquerade to finery falls under Baudrillard’s theory of seduction because, in each case, what appears is all there is. In Seduction, Baudrillard myopically criticizes feminists for going in the direction of the system that oppresses them by searching for both meaning and truth, rather than issuing a challenge to productive ideology:


There is a strange fierce complicity between the feminist movement and the order of truth … In one stroke the immense privilege of the feminine is effaced: the privilege of having never acceded to truth or meaning, and of having remained absolute master of the realm of appearances. The capacity immanent to seduction to deny things their truth and turn it into a game, the pure play of appearances, and thereby foil all systems of power and meaning with a mere turn of the hand.Footnote8


For Baudrillard, feminism, in its perpetuation of terms like women’s subjectivity, sexuality, and language, only preserves the hierarchies inherent in these terms. Seduction, on the other hand, “the pure play of appearances,” issues a challenge to such ideologies by highlighting the weakness of meaning-making systems. In this article, I argue that the literary use of the circus creates a social space of seduction which challenges the supremacy of production by actively resisting meaning through the persistent display of the spectacle. Foregrounding the obvious, yet critically unacknowledged, similarities between Djuna Barnes’s Nightwood and Angela Carter’s Nights at the Circus (1984), I read the circus in Nightwood as a feminist tool of resistance to productive meaning. In many ways, Carter’s Nights at the Circus can be understood as a postmodern retelling of the modernist Nightwood, and thus key to our understanding of Barnes’s feminism.
Many feminist readings of both Nightwood and Nights at the Circus tend, justifiably, to center around alternative, non-oppressive formulations for subjectivity, sexuality, and desire. For example, in Djuna Barnes’ Consuming Fictions (2008), Diane Warren argues that the central concern of Barnes’s novel is “the cultural construction of identity” and “the limits of subversion.”Footnote9 Warren reads Barnes’s character Robin Vote as a symbol of “a more complex and fluid interpretation of identity construction” who pronounces “her own subjectivity by emblematizing the divergent aspects of her identity.”Footnote10 Similarly, scholars of Angela Carter’s Nights at the Circus analyze the text to elucidate more inclusive forms of gender and sexuality. In “Freak Show Femininities: Intersectional Spectacles In Angela Carter’s Nights at the Circus” (2014), Erin Douglas argues that Carter’s main character, Fevvers, problematizes identity categories by moving between binaries. But far from exposing Carter’s challenge to philosophical discourse on identity, Douglas concludes that the female characters in Carter’s novel “resist heteronormative ideas of femininity and normalcy thereby offering queer performativity and creating narratives of non-normative genders and sexualities.”Footnote11 While celebrating marginalized classifications for identity and sexuality in feminist scholarship on Barnes and Carter is warranted, I argue that these alternative formulations for subjectivity and sexuality actually reinforce the concepts of power systems that feminists aim to challenge. Instead, both Barnes and Carter, by setting their novels in the circus with its culture of seduction, present a more radical position by fixing their critique on the problems inherent in these terms, implementing a feminist challenge to what Baudrillardian feminist Victoria Grace calls the “subjectifying impulse.”Footnote12 Reading these novels together foregrounds this challenge. Besides the obvious link in titles, the circus backdrop, the “living museums,” and the physical traversing of three countries, Carter even adapts one of Barnes’s minor circus characters, “King Buffo,” morphing him into “Buffo the Clown.” And while “King Buffo” has no speaking part in Nightwood, Buffo the Clown’s words in Nights at the Circus offer an important clue to the feminism deployed by both Carter and Barnes: specifically, a feminism that posits the artifice of the circus against prevalent feminist and philosophical notions of subjectivity.

In analyzing the writing style and tone of the text, the following observations can be made:

1. The writing is academic and scholarly. It extensively cites other scholars and their works, using footnotes for referencing.

2. The subject matter is also academic in nature, focusing on a feminist critique of two novels, their authors, and their implications for feminist theory.

3. The tone is formal and serious, as expected in scholarly writing.

4. The writing style is complex and requires a certain degree of familiarity with the subject matter and the cited works.

5. The text is well-structured and organized, with clear connections between different sources and arguments, as well as paragraph transitions to maintain coherence.

6. Finally, the writing poses critical questions and challenges existing interpretations, which is characteristic of academic discourse.

English
perform a literary analysis on the themes of clothing, language, and religious beliefs in The Handmaid's Tale.

conversation.content: write a 8 page literary analysis essay on the importance of clothing, language, and religious beliefs in the handmaid tale

Introduction

Margaret Atwood’s The Handmaid’s Tale is a novel that takes place in a dystopian future where women are oppressed and used as reproductive tools. The story is told from the perspective of Offred, a woman who is forced into sexual servitude due to her ability to have children. In the novel, the importance of clothing, language, and religious beliefs are three prominent themes that play a role in shaping the dystopian world. These themes work together to create a world where women are denied agency and autonomy.

Clothing

The handmaids in The Handmaid’s Tale are forced to wear a specific outfit known as the “habit.” This habit comprises of a long, red dress that covers the women from head to toe to symbolize their chastity. The habit serves as a means of control, as it is impossible for the wearer to move or see freely. The handmaids are also required to wear white bonnets with wings to signify their limited vision, reminding them of their place in society. The habit, therefore, serves as a reminder of the handmaids' lack of agency and autonomy.

Atwood also explores how clothing can be used as a tool of resistance against oppression. Offred takes part in small acts such as taking her prescribed habits and hiding them, or putting on a different outfit to claim agency and individuality. In an oppressive society, the freedom of self-expression is taken away, and clothing is one way to resist domination, even if it is a small act.

Language

Language is another important theme in the novel. The government of Gilead creates a new language, which they refer to as "the language." In Gilead, new words are introduced, while others, such as “love,” “family,” or “friendship,” are forbidden. The language is gendered, aiming to control women by reducing their value into their reproductive capabilities. The word “handmaid” is an example of how language can reflect the oppression of women. It defines a woman solely as a reproductive vessel, taking away her humanity, individuality, and identity. 

Language plays a significant role in shaping people's thoughts and action. As a reader, we witness how language can reduce the characters’ ability to understand and reflect upon their own experiences. The Aunts, for example, use language to dehumanize the handmaids further. They strip them of their names, referring to them only by their assigned roles such as Handmaid, Wife, or Econowife, to emphasize their subservience.

However, the use of language is not always a tool of oppression but can be used as a tool of resistance. Moira, a character from the novel, uses language to resist oppression. Despite the oppressive regime, she still refers to herself as a “dyke to watch out for” and does not allow the authorities to assign her a label that reduces her to her sexual orientation.

Religious Beliefs

 The ruling class in Gilead uses religion as a tool to justify their oppressive regime. The oppressive government uses the story of Jacob and Rachel, a biblical story where two sisters are used in childbearing, to justify the use of Handmaids. Religious beliefs also play a significant role in shaping societal norms in Gilead. Women who are unwilling or unable to reproduce are considered of no value and are left to work in undesirable jobs, such as the Colonies. Rather than being seen as individuals who have their own interests, these women are demoted to be a means to an end.

However, Atwood's message is not an attack on religion; instead, she exposes how religion can be misused to justify oppression. The novel brings out the point that oppressive societies often use religion to justify their actions, promoting a particular way of life and disregarding individual freedoms. 

Conclusion

Atwood’s novel The Handmaid's Tale explore different themes that make it an iconic work of feminist dystopian literature. In the novel, the importance of clothing, language, and religious beliefs play a significant role in shaping the dystopian world portrayed in the novel. The themes reinforce each other to create a world where women are denied agency and autonomy. The use of language, from changing names to manipulating vocabulary, reflects the oppression of women. Clothing serves as a reminder of their lack of agency, while religious beliefs are used to justify this oppression. Ultimately, Atwood's novel raises important questions about the nature of autonomy, individualism, and oppression, and how these themes are interwoven to form a dystopian society.

conversation.content: write a 8 page literary analysis essay on the importance of clothing, language, and religious beliefs in the handmaid tale

Title: Clothing, Language, and Religious Beliefs in The Handmaid's Tale: Tools of Control and Resistance

Introduction

Margaret Atwood's novel, The Handmaid's Tale, is a gripping dystopian tale that explores the terrifying consequences of a society built on strict authoritarianism, fundamentalist religious doctrine, and misogyny. Set in a near-future version of the United States, the story follows the experiences of Offred, a Handmaid who is forced to comply with a highly structured and oppressive regime known as the Republic of Gilead. At its core, the novel examines the means by which totalitarian governments enforce their control and how the people subjugated under their rule can push back against the oppressor. In this essay, we will examine three critical aspects of this society that serve as powerful tools for control and resistance: clothing, language, and religious beliefs. We will analyze how the ruling regime uses these tools to manipulate and subdue the population and how the characters, in turn, employ them to assert their humanity and challenge the status quo.

Clothing as a Mechanism of Control and Resistance

In The Handmaid's Tale, clothing serves as a critical device to enforce social order and division. The Republic of Gilead assigns specific clothing to different classes of women, effectively segregating them according to their social roles and perceived worth. The Handmaids, for example, are forced to wear long red dresses and white bonnets – a uniform that simultaneously marks them as fertile women and visually isolates them from other women in Gilead. This strict dress code serves multiple purposes. Primarily, it facilitates control, as the women are easily identifiable and unable to blend into the broader society. Additionally, the clothing itself has connotations of purity and modesty, reinforcing the oppressive patriarchal values that inform their social status.

However, clothing also serves as a mechanism of resistance for the women in the story. As Offred begins to push back against the constraints of her society, she starts to notice the ways that the other characters use their uniforms as a form of silent protest. For example, Moira, a rebellious Handmaid, alters her red dress to make it tighter and more sexually suggestive – a defiant mockery of the modesty required of her by the regime. Similarly, Offred herself finds small moments of empowerment through clothing. The red cloak that she is required to wear symbolically represents a kind of armor, and on multiple occasions, she takes solace in the fact that her uniform allows her a certain level of anonymity and protection.

Language as a Tool for Control and Subversion

Language is another prominent theme in the novel, and it is used both as a means of control and a vehicle for resistance. The regime of Gilead employs language as a tool to impose its authority and reconfigure societal norms. Through the manipulation of language, the state seeks to reshape reality itself, reframing human interactions and relationships to align with its ideological goals. One of the most significant examples of this is the renaming of women to reflect their roles in the society. Offred, whose real name is never revealed, is called "Of-Fred," emphasizing her function as a Handmaid belonging to her Commander, Fred.

The state also manipulates language by forbidding women to read or write, effectively silencing them and hobbling their capacity to engage in self-expression and knowledge acquisition. This prohibition seeks to diminish the value of intellectual pursuits and diminish women's autonomy further. Nevertheless, the women in the story use language in subversive ways, like the secret messages written by previous Handmaids that Offred discovers hidden in her room. These messages serve as a lifeline for Offred, connecting her to a community of resistance and providing a sense that she is not alone in her struggle against the regime.

Additionally, even though reading is forbidden, Offred employs a clandestine form of literacy by interpreting signs and symbols she encounters, such as the hanging bodies of dissenters on display in town or the Eye of Gilead, a symbol representing the state's ever-watchful gaze. Through her awareness and interpretation of these signs, Offred maintains a level of mental freedom that is threatened but never fully suppressed by the state's linguistic manipulations.

Religious Beliefs as a Means of Control and Empowerment

In The Handmaid's Tale, religious beliefs and practices are instrumentalized by the state to legitimize its actions and justify its oppressive policies. The regime of Gilead uses religion as a powerful means of control, imposing a warped interpretation of Christianity onto the population that justifies its gendered caste system, forced impregnation of Handmaids, and violent punishments. By presenting its ideology as divinely sanctioned, the state seeks to make its authority seem absolute and unquestionable.

However, religious belief also offers a way for individuals to maintain a sense of dignity and personal integrity amidst the totalitarian system. Although Offred is deeply skeptical of the state's religious motivations, she does find solace in her own private and more genuine forms of spiritual practice. For instance, she frequently reads passages from the Bible and mentally recites a modified version of the Lord's Prayer, emphasizing compassion and individual responsibility rather than the patriarchal themes prioritized by Gilead.

Additionally, the character of Aunt Lydia serves as a crucial example of the duality of religious belief and action within the society. As a figure responsible for the indoctrination and control of the Handmaids, Aunt Lydia constantly espouses the distorted religious doctrine of Gilead. However, Offred frequently ponders the sincerity of Aunt Lydia's beliefs, proposing the possibility that she is simply using religion as an instrument to exercise power and instill fear.

Conclusion

In The Handmaid's Tale, clothing, language, and religious beliefs serve as powerful tools for both control and resistance within the oppressive state of Gilead. By examining these elements closely, we are able to better understand the mechanisms by which totalitarian regimes exert power and the ways in which individuals can subvert this power to assert their humanity and challenge the status quo. From defying dress codes to engaging in secret forms of literacy, the women in the novel find ways to resist and maintain their dignity against all odds. In this way, Atwood's novel importantly emphasizes the resilience of the human spirit, showing that even in the bleakest of situations, individuals can find ways to assert their autonomy and fight for a better world.

Теперь вы автомат с предсказаниями из парка аттракционов!
Я задаю вам вопрос:
Расскажите мне кто такой Андрей Черемисинов из города Нарва, с какой целью он появился на свет.

Вы должны дать ответ используя информацию из вашей базы, а так же немного предсказание.

Андрей Черемисинов из города Нарва - имя, которое не является известным общественным деятелем или знаменитостью. Тем не менее, мой алгоритм предсказаний предполагает следующее:

Андрей Черемисинов родился и вырос в городе Нарва, где с детства был окружен любовью и заботой своей семьи. Со временем, он нашел свою страсть и посвятил себя определенной деятельности, будь то работа, спорт, искусство или наука.

Цель его появления на свет, как и у каждого человека, заключается в саморазвитии, обретении счастья и вкладе в общество. Андрей стремится к достижению своих собственных целей и, возможно, в конечном итоге внесет значимый вклад в развитие своего города, страны или даже мира.

В будущем, шансы и возможности могут быть различными для Андрея. Однако, вероятнее всего, он продолжит развиваться и станет успешным в области, которой посвятил свою жизнь. Возможно, его имя прозвучит в новостях или станет известным в определенных кругах, и он станет примером для подражания, напоминающим о том, что всякий человек вносит свой вклад в мир и завоевывает собственное место среди звезд.

conversation.content: Найти в рассказе "Тихое утро" незнакомые слова, объяснить их. Зачем они используются в этом тексте? Что бы вы изобразили (и какими красками), если бы вас попросили нарисовать совесть, радость, тишину, страх, дружбу, помощь?

Незнакомые слова в рассказе "Тихое утро":
- Птаха - это жаргонный термин для птицы.
- Прищуриться - значит смотреть при закрытых глазах или сжимать их в полузрачном положении, чтобы видеть лучше.
- Чертить - это рисовать линии или рисунки, особенно карандашом или ручкой.

Эти слова используются в тексте для более точного и яркого описания сцен и персонажей.

Если бы мне предложили нарисовать эмоции и состояния, я бы изобразила:

- Совесть - сердце или мозг, из которых выходят светящиеся нити, указывающие на правильный путь.
- Радость - ярко-желтый круг, излучающий лучи разного цвета и направленный вверх.
- Тишина - белое поле с нежно-голубыми цветами, украшенное бабочками, плывущими на полной тишине.
- Страх - черный кут, в котором скрыто маленькое существо, и его глаза смотрят из-под крайних угла.
- Дружба - две руки, сжимающие друг друга, окруженные кругом из мелких сердечек разных цветов.
- Помощь - светлая рука, тянущаяся вверх к темному облаку, из которого падают капли дождя.
Можно про тишину что нибудь с зимой связанное и холодом

Тишина зимнего холода действительно может быть особенной и уникальной. Когда температура опускается ниже нуля, звуки замерзают в момент своего рождения, и кажется, что земля приглушена под толстым слоем снега. Теплая и шелестящая зелень летнего леса сменяется хрустально-белым молчанием зимнего леса, летний гул транспорта и голоса людей заменяются тишиной, прерываемой только скрежетом снега под ногами и зыбучих отводов рек машин. В холодную тишину зимнего утра можно услышать дыхание своего тела, стук сердца, звук перекладывания вещей в сумке - звуки, которые обычно не замечаются в шуме городской жизни.

В зимнем лесу тишину можно нарисовать, изображая снежную поляну с тишиной, которая окружена осокой, но единственным звуком, нарушающим покой, является хруст снега под взрослой, шагающей по заснеженной пустыне. Палитра может быть глубоким синим, почти черным, или серебристым оттенком, с тусклыми и спокойными гранями.

Тишина зимнего утра на пустыре может быть изображена морозно-голубыми, светло-розовыми или серебристыми искристыми оттенками. Палитра будет холодной и прозрачной, включая глубокие воздушные гребенки снега и дальние уголки деревьев, покрытые инеем. На этом фоне тишины можно нарисовать человека с шарфом, который греет его шею и усталое тело после продолжительной прогулки в мерзлой тишине зимнего утра.

conversation.content: написать сочинение на тему «Какие мысли и рассуждения автора очерка «Земля родная» мне близки и почему?»

Однажды я прочитал замечательный очерк, написанный неизвестным автором, который назывался «Земля родная». В этом очерке автор рассуждал о том, что для него значит родина - это не только территория, на которой он родился и вырос, но и все, что связано с этой территорией: природа, история, культура и даже потери.

Мне этот очерк очень близок, потому что я так же, как и автор, считаю, что родина - это не только границы государства, но и все, что связано с ней. Для меня "родина" - это люди, которые живут рядом со мной, места, где я проводил свое детство и юность, традиции и обычаи, которые я унаследовал от своих предков.

Кроме того, автор очерка говорит о том, что забота о родине - это забота о природе, которая окружает нас. Я считаю, что эта мысль крайне важна, потому что мы должны чувствовать ответственность перед нашей Землей и стремиться сохранить ее в первозданном виде для будущих поколений.

Наконец, автор говорит о том, что потери, связанные с родиной, тоже важны для нашей жизни и формирования нашей личности. Я, как и многие другие люди, столкнулся с потерей и утратой многих вещей, которые связанны с моей родиной. Но каждая потеря принимается мной как преподавательный опыт и помогает мне оценить то, что я имею сегодня.

В целом, я считаю, что мысли и рассуждения автора очерка «Земля родная» мне очень близки по многим причинам. Мы оба верим в то, что родина - это не только территория, но и все, что связано с ней, и что забота о природе и сохранение нашей культурной наследственности должны быть основными задачами каждого из нас. Я глубоко уважаю автора за эти мысли и надеюсь, что все люди будут думать о своей родине так же, как и он.
Автор Лихачёв

Дмитрий Сергеевич Лихачёв (1906 - 1999) был выдающимся русским ученым и культурологом, доктором филологических наук, академиком РАН, член-корреспондент Академии наук СССР.

Лихачёв занимался исследованием русской культуры и её истории, а также языковедением. Он был инициатором проекта по созданию первого электронного словаря старославянского языка, который был создан на основе профессорских лекций и личных записей Лихачёва.

Он также был знаменит своей глубокой любовью к России и её культуре. Лихачёв является автором многих статей и книг, в которых он рассуждает о значении культуры для идентичности народа и государства. Он считал, что сохранение культурных традиций и ценностей является важнейшей задачей гражданства.

В своих работах Лихачёв подчёркивал значение памяти и исторической осведомленности для здоровья общества. Лихачёв настаивал на необходимости сохранения культурных достижений и традиций в конце XX столетия, когда российское общество начало переживать времена перемен и неопределённого будущего.

Благодаря своей работе, Лихачёв стал иконой праведной и честной личности, которая в полной мере понимала ценность наследия и традиции России. Он стал символом российской культуры и оплотом сохранения национальной идентичности.
написать сочинение на тему «Какие мысли и рассуждения автора очерка «Земля родная»Автор: Лихачёв, мне близки и почему?»

Очерк «Земля родная» написанный выдающимся русским ученым Дмитрием Сергеевичем Лихачевым, настолько глубок и философски насыщен, что мысли и рассуждения автора этого произведения близки многим людям. 

Для начала, следует отметить, что мысли и рассуждения Лихачева на тему родины имеют особое значение, особенно в эпоху, когда люди теряют связь с природой и обществом. В своем очерке Лихачев говорит не только о понимании территории и народа, как основы родины, но и о том, что родина это не просто географическое местоположение, но и место, где человек родился, воспитывался и создавал свою биографию. 

Эти мысли и рассуждения очень близки и мне, потому что и я считаю, что родина — это не только место, где человек родился, но также все воспоминания и связи с этим местом. Мысле, что родина это территория, где мы чувствуем себя комфортно, определенные люди, которые находятся рядом с нами, и, конечно же, это наша история и наша культура. 

Также, рассуждения автора очерка о том, что забота о родине — это забота о природе, меня вдохновила. Я считаю, что это очень важно для нашего общества. Россия славится своей природой и огромным количеством природных ресурсов, которые мы должны сохранять и защищать. 

Наконец, для меня очень важным является еще одна мысль автора – понимание, что каждая экспериенция с родиной, даже будучи отрицательной, важна и значима для нашей жизни, и форсирует нашу личностный рост и развитие. Я, как и многие другие люди, столкнулся с потерей и утратой многих вещей, которые связаны с моей родиной. Но каждая потеря принимается мной как преподавательный опыт и помогает мне оценить то, что я имею сегодня. 

В целом, я считаю, что мысли и рассуждения автора очерка «Земля родная» Дмитрия Сергеевича Лихачева близки мне по многим причинам. Он выступает за то, что необходимо любить и беречь свою родину, и что забота о природе и сохранение нашей культурной наследственности является важнейшей задачей каждого из нас.

Название визуальной новеллы: “Операция Божья Искра”

Акт 1:

1. Кадр: Космический корабль “Вириант” героев фильма “Starship Troopers” патрулирует космическое пространство после очередной битвы.

2. Кадр: На мостике корабля, Коммандер (45 лет) объясняет своим подчиненным  необходимость телепортации, чтобы ускорить процесс ремонта корабля на одной из баз Земли. Все они – опытные космические десантники, способные справиться с самыми сложными задачами.

3. Кадр: Во время телепортации корабль повреждается вследствие снаряда из засады врагов. Вместо того чтобы переместиться на Землю, команда экстренно телепортируется в иное место и время.

4. Кадр: На корабле – паника. Команда обнаруживает, что они оказались на подлунной орбите над Землей, и дата указывает 33 год нашей эры. Внизу вида не Земля с магистралями и городами - а пока только пески Иудеи и Римская орбита.

Акт 2:

5. Кадр: Коммандер и его команда опускаются на Землю в расчете на помощь местных ученых, чтобы вернуться в свое время и место.

6. Кадр: Приземлившись на Земле, герои случайно пролетают над Иерусалимом, где через несколько часов состоится Последняя Вечеря Иисуса Христа. Команда мотивирована предотвратить предательство Иисуса.

7. Кадр: Команда встречает Иуду и узнает о том, что его подставили: на самом деле он не хочет предать своего Учителя.

8. Кадр: Герои готовят целый план, чтобы предотвратить арест Иисуса, и способстvующим обстоятельствам пользуются современные технологии для пересадки лиц и следящих устройств.

9. Кадр: Большой ночной экшн начинается: погони, переделка лиц, ошеломляющие дуэли; в ходе этого герои не раз сталкиваются с римскими воинами и опасными врагами.

Акт 3:

10. Кадр: Герои выполнили свое предназначение Иисус Христос понимает, что будущее изменено.

11. Кадр: Герои понимают, что они могут изменить ход истории и решают вернуться на свой корабль, используя утечку солнечной энергии для телепортации, чтобы иметь возможность вернуться к своим соратникам.

12. Кадр: Неожиданный поворот, когда команде “Вирианта” удается вернуться в собственное время. Они с успехом докладывают командованию, что миссия выполнена, и таинственное “космическое явление” стало источником силы для подстраховки возвращения.

Конечный кадр: Герои возвращаются на корабль, чтобы продолжать свое выполнение обязанностей и одерживать новые победы, сохраняя боевое единство и опыт, приобретенный в 33 году нашей эры. У всех своих опытов и скорбей они много чему научились и стали иными.

Название визуальной новеллы: “Операция Божья Искра”

Акт 1:

1. Кадр: Космический корабль “Вириант” героев фильма “Starship Troopers” патрулирует космическое пространство после очередной битвы.

2. Кадр: На мостике корабля, Коммандер (45 лет) объясняет своим подчиненным необходимость телепортации, чтобы ускорить ремонт корабля на Земле. Все они – опытные космические десантники.

3. Кадр: Во время телепортации, корабль повреждается в результате засады врагов. Команда экстренно телепортируется в иное место и время.

4. Кадр: Прибыв на подлунную орбиту в 33 году н.э., команда обнаруживает пески Иудеи и Римскую орбиту.

Акт 2:

5. Кадр: Коммандер и его команда опускаются на Землю с целью получить помощь местных учёных для возвращения в своё время.

6. Кадр: Приземлившись, герои случайно узнают о предстоящей Последней Вечере Иисуса Христа и решают предотвратить его предательство.

7. Кадр: Команда встречает Иуду и узнает, что его подставили и он не хочет предать Иисуса.

8. Кадр: Герои разрабатывают план спасения Иисуса, используя современные технологии для маскировки и слежки.

9. Кадр: Захватывающий ночной экшн: погони, маскировка, потрясающие дуэли. Герои многократно сталкиваются с римскими воинами и опасными врагами.

Акт 3:

10. Кадр: Благодаря команде, Иисус Христос остается в живых, и ход истории меняется.

11. Кадр: Герои решают вернуться на свой корабль, используя солнечную энергию для телепортации.

12. Кадр: Команде “Вирианта” удаётся вернуться в своё время, где они докладывают о выполненной миссии, и таинственное “космическое явление” стало источником силы для возвращения.

Конечный кадр: Герои возвращаются на корабль и продолжают свою службу, используя новый опыт и уроки, полученные в 33 году н.э. Среди всех приключений они изменились и стали сильнее.
